messages.text: [ANN] FlatGeobuf 0.1 has been released :tada: . <https://github.com/evetion/FlatGeobuf.jl>. It's a parser of the flatgeobuf format (<https://bjornharrtell.github.io/flatgeobuf/>), a replacement of shapefiles and other formats based on flatbuffers. It's a work in progress, but the basics are there.

attachments.title: FlatGeobuf
attachments.text: A performant binary encoding for geographic data based on flatbuffers

elements.text: . It's a parser of the flatgeobuf format (
), a replacement of shapefiles and other formats based on flatbuffers. It's a work in progress, but the basics are there.

messages.text:
[ANN] GeoDataFrames 0.1 has also been released :tada: , see <https://github.com/evetion/GeoDataFrames.jl>. It's a simple wrapper on top of ArchGDAL that should make things easier. I saw a lot of questions/posts/issues on Slack/Discourse/Github on how to write shapefiles etc, while I needed a similar thing as well. It's still a work in progress, things will change (upstream) still.
```using GeoDataFrames; const GDF=GeoDataFrames
using DataFrames

coords = zip(rand(10), rand(10))
df = DataFrame(geom=createpoint.(coords), name="test");
GDF.write("test_points.shp", df)```

elements.text: . It's a simple wrapper on top of ArchGDAL that should make things easier. I saw a lot of questions/posts/issues on Slack/Discourse/Github on how to write shapefiles etc, while I needed a similar thing as well. It's still a work in progress, things will change (upstream) still.

using GeoDataFrames; const GDF=GeoDataFrames
using DataFrames

coords = zip(rand(10), rand(10))
df = DataFrame(geom=createpoint.(coords), name="test");
GDF.write("test_points.shp", df)

messages.text: <@U88813859> GeoDataFrames looks great, but I'm having issues with plotting after a reprojection. It might be my problem, since I'm learning about these things as I play with some data I have. I'll keep playing some more.

messages.text: Hey, this is somewhat of a vague question as I am largely unfamiliar with the Julia Geo community but what is the Julia geo package ecosystem like compared to Python - particularly to geopandas and folium? I desire to work with Julia for my data analysis but am curious if I will need to supplement my work with python packages via PyCall. Thanks all! _P.S. I am not asking exactly about community/adoption sort of stuff - Python has been around much longer than Julia so I don't expect Geo Julia to have as much. However, if it has the essentials, then heck yea! I can do my analysis in Julia!_ :juliaheartpulse-dark:

elements.text: Hey, this is somewhat of a vague question as I am largely unfamiliar with the Julia Geo community but what is the Julia geo package ecosystem like compared to Python - particularly to geopandas and folium? I desire to work with Julia for my data analysis but am curious if I will need to supplement my work with python packages via PyCall. Thanks all!

P.S. I am not asking exactly about community/adoption sort of stuff - Python has been around much longer than Julia so I don't expect Geo Julia to have as much. However, if it has the essentials, then heck yea! I can do my analysis in Julia!

messages.text:
Anyone here has worked with GeoJSON.jl package?
The basic usage on the docs isnt working for me
<https://juliageo.org/GeoJSON.jl/stable/#GeoJSON.jl-1>

`using GeoJSON`
`osm_buildings = """`
`{`
    `"type": "FeatureCollection",`
    `"features": [{`
        `"type": "Feature",`
        `"geometry": {`
            `"type": "Polygon",`
            `"coordinates": [`
                `[`
                    `[13.42634, 52.49533],`
                    `[13.42630, 52.49529],`
                    `[13.42640, 52.49525],`
                    `[13.42611, 52.49494],`
                    `[13.42590, 52.49501],`
                    `[13.42583, 52.49495],`
                    `[13.42619, 52.49483],`
                    `[13.42660, 52.49524],`
                    `[13.42634, 52.49533]`
                `]`
            `]`
        `},`
        `"properties": {`
            `"color": "rgb(255,200,150)",`
            `"height": 150`
        `}`
    `}]`
`}"""`
`buildings = GeoJSON.read(osm_buildings)`

I am getting error as
`ERROR: SystemError: opening file "{\n    \"type\": \"FeatureCollection\",\n    \"features\": [{\n        \"type\": \"Feature\",\n        \"geometry\": {\n            \"type\": \"Polygon\",\n            \"coordinates\": [\n                [\n                    [13.42634, 52.49533],\n                    [13.42630, 52.49529],\n                    [13.42640, 52.49525],\n                    [13.42611, 52.49494],\n                    [13.42590, 52.49501],\n                    [13.42583, 52.49495],\n                    [13.42619, 52.49483],\n                                        [13.42660, 52.49524],\n                    [13.42634, 52.49533]\n                ]\n            ]\n        },\n        \"properties\": {\n            \"color\": \"rgb(255,200,150)\",\n            \"height\": 150\n        }\n    }]\n}": File name too long`

messages.text: For those who are interested in JuliaGeo GitHub organization related issues, it's a good idea to watch the meta repository. For instance I just created <https://github.com/JuliaGeo/meta/issues/15>, to switch CI over to GitHub Actions.

messages.text: Finally switched over from GDAL 3.0 directly to 3.2, so new formats (COG, FlatGeobuf), and many other improvements: <https://github.com/JuliaGeo/GDAL.jl/pull/108|https://github.com/JuliaGeo/GDAL.jl/pull/108>

messages.text: Is there a way to intersect a bunch of linestrings and return a new collection of linestrings with an attribute of # of intersections for each new feature/geometry? I figure that GIS in Julia isn't quite that far along in development, but wanted to check just in case!

messages.text:
Why would below snippet of code spend almost all of its time in GC ?
`_const_ GJ = GeoJSON`
`_const_ GI = GeoInterface`
`@time Threads.@threads _for_ h _in_ highways`
    `write(open("/home/data/osm_split/highways_" * string(h[1]) * ".geojson", "w"), GJ.write(GI.FeatureCollection(h[2])))`
_`end`_

Time:
`8215.429909 seconds (835.49 M allocations: 67.452 GiB, 99.89% gc time)`
